{
  "number": "10",
  "is_real_bug": true,
  "is_fixed": false,
  "found_pointer": [
    {
      "type": "Commit Hash",
      "value": "c48a6ed63473bfdc78f813723e5aa20a7c983b71"
    },
    {
      "type": "Other",
      "value": "pcre2test.c around line 2589 (use of fseek on stdin)"
    }
  ],
  "fixed_pointer": [],
  "bug_kind": "OTHER",
  "how_found": "MANUAL_REVIEW",
  "reproduction_pattern_and_input": [
    {
      "pattern": "^match",
      "input": "(pcre2grep -m1 -A3 '^match'; echo '---'; head -1) < testdata/grepinput"
    }
  ],
  "log": "```
./testdata/grepoutput expects an 'a' at the end.
---------------------------- Test 132 -----------------------------
match 1:
 a
match 2:
 b
---
 a
RC=0

```
I actually get no 'a' when I run RunGrepTest:
```
---------------------------- Test 132 -----------------------------
match 1:
 a
match 2:
 b
---
RC=0

```
Manually running this test I can't see how it produces 'a' after the '---':
```
$ (pcre2grep -m1 -A3 '^match'; echo '---'; head -1) < testdata/grepinput
match 1:
 a
match 2:
 b
---
```

PH: The idea of this test is to check that the standard input is left in the right place when pcre2grep stops because it has reached the -m limit. The "a" line is generated by the "head -1" command when run under Linux (which is all I have):

```
$ (./pcre2grep -m1 -A3 '^match'; echo '---'; head -1) < testdata/grepinput
match 1:
 a
match 2:
 b
---
 a
```

Looks like this is yet another Linux/BSD difference. Sigh. I think the relevant code is around line 2589 in pcre2test.c:

```
  /* If the -m option set a limit for the number of matched or non-matched
  lines, check it here. A limit of zero means that no matching is ever done.
  For stdin from a file, set the file position. */                         
                                                                            
  if (count_limit >= 0 && count_matched_lines >= count_limit)             
    {                                                                   
    if (frtype == FR_PLAIN && filename == stdin_name && !is_file_tty(handle))
      (void)fseek(handle, (long int)filepos, SEEK_SET);             
    rc = (count_limit == 0)? 1 : 0;                                     
    break;                                                             
    }
```",
  "summary": "The issue reports that RunGrepTest produces different output on BSD-like systems because pcre2test.c uses fseek() on stdin to rewind a text stream, which is not portable and yields different behavior across OSes. This is a real portability bug in the test harness (not regex semantics) reproducible with the provided command using pattern '^match' and testdata/grepinput. The report cites a prototype fix in a fork (commit c48a6ed6...) and points to pcre2test.c around line 2589; no upstream fix is indicated in the issue. I classify it as OTHER because it is a genuine functional/portability defect in test code rather than a crash, memory, or performance bug."
}

This is a real crash bug (platform-specific) caused by improper handling of W^X on Darwin/iOS. The bug was found via manual testing on iPhone OS 14.5.1 (reporter demonstrated failures on pcre2-10.42) and while the reporter found a local workaround (defining SLJIT_WX_EXECUTABLE_ALLOCATOR and using a POSIX allocator, with tests passing on pcre2-10.43 in an unsandboxed environment), there is no evidence the fix was merged upstream, so it is not marked fixed here."

  "log": null,
  "summary": "The report describes that compiling with PARTIAL_HARD and MATCH_INVALID_UTF does not return a partial match for a single leading byte of a multibyte UTF-8 sequence. This is expected: MATCH_INVALID_UTF causes anything that is not perfectly valid UTF to be ignored, so an incomplete multibyte subject is not treated as a partial UTF match. The comment shows that if you are not in UTF mode (no PCRE2_UTF nor PCRE2_MATCH_INVALID_UTF) a partial match for the single byte is produced. Therefore this is a usage/semantics issue rather than a bug in PCRE2." 
}

  "log": null,
  "summary": "The reporter expected /(a(?R)b)/ to match 'aabb' but PCRE2 returned no match. Comments correctly explain that (?R) recurses to the entire pattern with no base case, which does not yield a successful match (and can create an infinite recursion); a terminating alternative such as /(a(?:(?R)|)b)/ is needed. This is a usage/misunderstanding of recursion semantics, not a defect in PCRE2, and the reporter acknowledged the explanation. Therefore it is not a real bug."
}

```

Before #474, `\xe1` would be included in the starting code units when `\xc1` was in a leading char class, and caseless mode was enabled. Now it is not.

Further, such a char class no longer matches `\xe1`, whereas previously it did. This is not just the starting code point optimization causing early failure of the match... see the above test case with `no_start_optimize`.

For reference, these are the results on the commit just before #474:

  3     [Aa\xc1\xe1]
 36  36 Ket
 39     End
------------------------------------------------------------------

Starting code units: A a \xc1 \xe1
Subject length lower bound = 1
    \x{e1}
 0: \xe1

/[a\x{c1}]/iI,ucp,no_start_optimize
------------------------------------------------------------------
  0  36 Bra
  3     [Aa\xc1\xe1]
 36  36 Ket
 39     End
------------------------------------------------------------------
Capture group count = 0
Options: caseless no_start_optimize ucp
Optimizations: auto_possess,dotstar_anchor
    \x{e1}
 0: \xe1
```",

The behavior was verified by bisecting to #474 and comparing engine diagnostics before and after the change; the failing examples (with and without start-optimization) are provided. This is a real semantic bug because the engine's matching/case-equivalence behavior changed incorrectly; no fix is indicated in the issue. The bug was discovered by manual investigation (bisecting) and affects case-folding/char-class handling. "
